title: Grades 6-8: American Sign Language, Level II
subject: Languages Other Than English (2014-)

document.title: Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills for Languages Other Than English

7C571AE17B1E4182BB8E4104E5795AA2.description: show evidence of becoming a lifelong learner by using ASL at the novice-to-intermediate proficiency level for personal enrichment and career development.

37A2CD6D8744436E9E70A3FF3E197B4C.description: use technology to communicate with the Deaf/ASL community; and

B1B0E9BF7D5B47D49AC8BC78F3960943.description: apply ASL at the novice-to-intermediate proficiency level in or out of the school setting through involvement in cultural activities such as attending Deaf events;

26016B5506AF44F68F60D0AA79E75B26.description: Communities. The student participates in the Deaf/ASL community by using ASL. The student is expected to:

AEADAC7175104C20BD168E42491FBA67.description: demonstrate an understanding of how one language and culture can influence another.

5DD2717A98C441C3AE4EA4848A987178.description: demonstrate an understanding of the nature of culture through comparisons of the student's own culture and the American Deaf culture; and

6147451E9FF6419D997241366B1370C5.description: demonstrate an understanding of the nature of language through comparisons of the student's own language and ASL;

06AD6E8B68554A5F920A9BB42F70088D.description: Comparisons. The student develops or expands insight into the nature of language and culture by comparing the student's own language and culture to ASL and American Deaf culture. The student is expected to:

965D11B4AECE428ABB231B0B0F26097C.description: use ASL to obtain, reinforce, or expand knowledge of other subject areas.

859E3DE8C8D849FFB268F3178D06C170.description: use resources and digital technology to gain access to information about ASL and Deaf culture; and

E95B6824E5464BA588694CB8802426E9.description: Connections. The student uses ASL to make connections with other subject areas and to acquire information. The student is expected to:

D164953A11CF43EC95BBC988872DD1D1.description: demonstrate an understanding of Deaf history and how it applies to the perspectives of American Deaf culture.

778FF23DA9EF40038B872F8C2A85D038.description: show evidence of appreciation of the contributions to arts and sciences by the Deaf and how they are applied to the perspectives of American Deaf culture; and

121ADD1642C745A1BF00CE979CDD81A4.description: show evidence of appreciation of ASL literature created by the Deaf and how it applies to the perspectives of American Deaf culture;

CE3E3B387D044EB5BDD76762C9F5CB78.description: recognize and use Deaf cultural norms to demonstrate, in writing or ASL, an understanding of the perspectives of American Deaf culture;

5753C61D75C844C2AFD750DA837AC20C.description: Cultures. The student gains knowledge and understanding of American Deaf culture. The student is expected to:

2470191458684FD7A8A6E291DDB7AE2B.description: create and express ASL literature, including handshape stories, that follows traditional cultural features.

536C48BD6B304F6D8BB7DB1729DC8EFF.description: demonstrate appropriate usage of ASL phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, and pragmatics; and

704A76B1D8A9486091EDDFE9DCE0F992.description: convey information in ASL using concepts, classifiers, phrases, and sentences to others without voice;

1EDEC0A02445463CBEAF8B73E0DD20D6.description: demonstrate an understanding of ASL such as stories, everyday commands, and instructions when dealing with familiar topics;

DBFA028E1DDC45B2A5E929488EC9236C.description: engage in a variety of ASL exchanges of learned material to socialize and to provide and obtain information;

B488F3ED16D443B4B890072535F46181.description: Communication. The student communicates in ASL using expressive and receptive communication skills without voice. The student is expected to:
